;;奥地利联邦铁路 Nightjet 卧铺列车准备从维也纳总站出发，乘务员在站台上等待。
;

;欧洲各国政府“系统地”缩减铁路规模，资金匮乏，同时投入资金扩大公路网络，;一份报告;发现。

;

;根据数据显示，1995 年至 2020 年间，欧洲高速公路长度增长了 60%，而铁路长度则缩减了 6.5%来自德国智库;伍珀塔尔研究所;和;T3的研究交通;。政府每花费 1 欧元修建铁路，就会花费 1.6 欧元修建道路。

;

;“这是一个政治选择，”绿色和平组织的气候活动人士 Lorelei Limousin 表示，该组织委托撰写了这份报告。 “我们今天看到了气候带来的后果，也看到了那些没有汽车替代解决方案的人们。”

;

;报告发现欧盟、挪威、瑞士和英国花费了 1.5 兆欧元（ 1995 年至 2018 年间，扩建公路的费用为 1.29 兆英镑，但扩建铁路网络的费用仅为 0.93 兆英镑（0.8 兆英镑）。

;

;在接下来的四年（2018-21 年）中，平均铁路和公路投资缺口从66%下降到34%。在此期间，奥地利、比利时、丹麦、法国、意大利、卢森堡和英国等七个国家在铁路上的投资多于公路，而其余国家在公路上的投资多于铁路。

;

;朱利奥·马蒂奥利 (Giulio Mattioli) 博士，多特蒙德工业大学的交通研究员没有参与这项研究，他表示：“大多数欧洲国家实际上一直在通过投入大量公共资金扩大高速公路基础设施来鼓励汽车的使用。”

;

;马蒂奥利补充说，在公众和政治辩论中，对自行车道和铁路的小额投资受到严格审查，而对道路的投资则被视为理所当然。 “如果我们要实现交通运输领域的气候缓解目标，这种情况绝对需要改变。”

;

;报告发现，爱尔兰、罗马尼亚和波兰的高速公路增长最快，立陶宛、拉脱维亚和比利时的高速公路增长最少。在所研究的 30 个国家中，有 15 个国家的高速公路长度在 25 年间增加了一倍多。

; ;

;同时报告发现，自20世纪90年代中期以来，欧洲各国政府已关闭了2500多个火车站。他们还关闭了约 8,523 英里（13,717 公里）的地区客运铁路线。研究人员表示，粗略估计，这些线路中的 4536 英里可以“相对容易地”重新开放。

;

;欧盟计划到本十年末将其温室气体排放量从 1990 年的水平减少 55%但交通运输领域却未能取得任何进展。 2020 年，道路运输占该行业排放量的四分之三。欧洲环境署表示，只有到 2029 年，国内运输排放量才会降至 1990 年的水平以下 ;推出了更便宜的公共交通票; 鼓励人们从汽车转向火车、电车和公共汽车。去年夏天，德国政府;推出了每月 9 欧元的当地和地区公共交通车票;，后来;提高到每月 49 欧元;。

;

;Mattioli 说：“9 欧元和 49 欧元的德国门票已经给了许多人的印象是，如果公共交通更便宜，人们就会转向公共交通。但服务水平和基础设施网络对于模式转变更为重要。所以我认为我们应该少谈论票价，多谈论基础设施。”

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 08:52:02 +0800 Authorities locate debris of F-35 fighter jet that crashed in South Carolinahttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/18/us-stealth-f-35-fighter-jet-crash-south-carolina-update

;;海军陆战队周一宣布，战斗机坠毁后将暂停行动两天。
;

;当局周一发现了一架海军陆战队 F-35 隐形战斗机的残骸场，该战斗机在飞行员弹射并跳伞安全后在南卡罗来纳州坠毁。

;

;据报道，残骸场位于威廉斯堡县农村地区。海军陆战队查尔斯顿联合基地。该场地位于基地东北部约两小时车程处，在恢复小组努力确保其安全的同时，居民被要求避开该区域。

;
;

;;相关：; ;在“事故”导致飞行员弹射后，美国军方寻求帮助寻找失踪的 F-35 战斗机;

;
;

;自从飞行员发生事故以来，当局一直在寻找这架飞机，周日下午 2 点左右，这名男子的名字尚未公布，他被降落伞安全地带到北查尔斯顿的一个社区。海军陆战队少校梅兰妮·萨利纳斯说，他被送往医院，目前情况稳定。

;

;海军陆战队周一宣布，在战斗机坠毁后，海军陆战队将暂停行动两天，这是美国第三次损失惨重的事故。最近几周。

;

;海军陆战队代理司令埃里克·史密斯将军下令停火，同时当局在南卡罗来纳州的两个湖泊附近搜寻失踪的 FB-35B 闪电 II 飞机。

; <根据海军陆战队的公告，这是过去六周内第三起被记录为“A 级事故”的事件。当损失达到 250 万美元或以上、国防部飞机被摧毁、有人死亡或永久残疾时，就会发生此类事件。

;

;指挥官将在停战期间加强安全飞行政策、实践和程序根据周一发布的消息，他们的海军陆战队人员。

;

;该公告没有提供有关前两起事件的详细信息。但今年8月，三名美国海军陆战队员在澳大利亚训练演习中因一架V-22B鱼鹰倾转旋翼机坠毁身亡，一名海军陆战队飞行员在训练飞行期间驾驶的战斗机在圣地亚哥基地附近坠毁身亡。第二海军陆战队飞机联队的海军陆战队员克里斯蒂安·科尔特斯下士表示，南卡罗来纳州对这架战斗机的搜寻工作周一正在进行。他说，具体发生的事情正在调查中。

;

;查尔斯顿联合基地的高级军士希瑟·斯坦顿表示，根据失踪飞机的位置和轨迹，搜索重点是莫尔特里湖和马里恩湖。这两个湖都位于北查尔斯顿以北。

;

;斯坦顿说，在该地区一些恶劣天气消失后，南卡罗来纳州执法部门的一架直升机加入了搜索。军方官员周日在网上发帖呼吁公众帮助寻找飞机。

;

;萨利纳斯说，第二架 F-35 的飞行员安全返回查尔斯顿联合基地。

;

;这些飞机和飞行员隶属于海军陆战队战斗机攻击训练中队 501，该中队隶属于第二海军陆战队飞机联队，基地位于南卡罗来纳州海岸附近的博福特。

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 07:52:02 +0800 ‘Size of a small police force’ of Met officers are suspended or on restricted dutieshttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/sep/19/police-met-officers-suspended-or-restricted-duties
;;2023-09-18T23:01:42Z;
;
;;大都会警车
;

;苏格兰场表示需要数年时间才能铲除在职的流氓警官

;

;英国最大的警察部队透露，有 201 名警察被停职，860 名警察执行限制任务，相当于沃里克郡或沃里克郡的规模。威尔特郡警察部队。大都会警察局有 34,000 名警察。

;

;大卫·卡里克 (David Carrick) 和韦恩·库森斯 (Wayne Couzens) 的罪行促使大都会内部对文化和标准进行彻底改革，导致过去 12 年间有 100 人因严重不当行为而被解雇警方表示，比历史平均水平增长了 66%。

;

;一直领导改革的副助理局长斯图尔特·康迪 (Stuart Cundy) 表示，这项工作还需要数年时间才能完成。他说，这个过程中的一个“悖论”意味着他们工作越努力，就越多的不当行为和可能的犯罪案件就会被发现。

;

;Cundy 说：“我们工作越努力，付出的努力就越多，精力也就越多。我们投入到识别那些不应该从事警察工作的人，并在现有的法规和法律中尽我们所能，越困难的案件，越困难的故事就会被公开，这是正确的。

; < p>;“这不是我们作为大都会警察可以单独解决的问题，也不是我们可以在一个月、六个月内解决的问题......这将需要一年、两年或更长时间才能根除这些问题”

;

;清理大都会的工作是在英格兰和威尔士的警察监管机构表示“公众对警察的信任岌岌可危”之际进行的。

;

; >;

;英国皇家警察和消防救援服务监察局 (HMICFRS) 负责人安迪·库克 (Andy Cooke) 在其最近的年度评估中要求赋予全面的新权力，以迫使警察部队应对他所称的最严重的法律和救援危机。人们记忆中的秩序。

;

;他说，在警察受到不可挽回的损害之前，恢复公众对警察的信任的机会有限。

;

;自从卡里克被定罪以来，一名现役警官被揭露为< a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/jan/16/how-met-police-officer-david-carrick-terrorized-women-over-two-decades">;其中之一英国最严重的连环性犯罪者;，已查明 1,600 起案件，其中警员在过去 10 年里面临家庭暴力或性暴力指控，但没有采取任何行动。

;

;大约有 450 项调查

;

;伦敦警察厅还公布了有关纪律程序的最新数据，包括：

;
    ;
  • ;

    ;过去有 100 名官员因严重不当行为而被解雇今年，比正常水平增加了 66%。

    ;
    • ;
  • ;

    ;201 名警员被停职，高于去年 9 月的 69 名。

    ;
    • ;
  • ; < p>;275 人正在等待严重不当行为听证会，其中很大一部分涉及涉嫌暴力侵害妇女和女童行为，而去年有 136 人。

    ;
    • ;
  • ;

    ;公众举报的数量涉嫌不当行为的警员数量增加了一倍。

    ;
    • ;
;

;警方还根据警察国家计算机上的记录检查了所有警员，发现了 11 起案件需要进一步评估，其中 5 起案件正在调查中。现在正在对严重不当行为进行调查。

;

;所有大都会雇员、文职人员和警察的详细信息也根据警察国家数据库中的情报记录进行了检查。有 14 人因潜在的严重不当行为而接受进一步调查，还会增加更多案件。

;

;Cundy 说，在所有审查的案件中，最严重的案件涉及强奸指控。

;

;一份单独的报告是该改革计划是由卡里克和库曾斯共同推动的，他们被判犯有绑架、强奸和谋杀罪。莎拉·埃弗拉德（Sarah Everard）在服役期间被谋杀，她曾是 PADP 的一部分。

;

;该部门的官员负责保护议会财产，包括威斯敏斯特宫以及首都各地的大使馆。大多数警官都携带武器。

;

;Leven 行动的调查结果已提供给路易丝·凯西 (Louise Casey)，她于 3 月份发表了关于大都会标准和文化的谴责性报告。

;

;副助理局长劳伦斯·泰勒 (Laurence Taylor)表示，Leven 行动审查发现 PADP 存在“不健康的工作文化”，原因是“缺乏多样性、监管缺失程度较低且程度最低，以及与大都会的脱节感”和士气低落。

;

;“这是非常明显，需要更好的领导，官员需要更好的监督，他们需要更好的培训，他们需要更好的装备，”泰勒说。

;

;在带来的变化中，泰勒表示，大都会警察局的目标是将指挥部中的女性人数增加到 20%，将黑人、亚裔和少数族裔军官的人数增加到 20%。

;抗议活动在利比亚爆发利比亚德尔纳市周一发生洪水，造成数千名居民死亡并摧毁了整个社区，数百人向当局发泄愤怒，并要求追究责任。

;
;

;;相关：;;“我从没想过我们会活下来”：洪水过后的德尔纳;;

;

;周一的抗议标志着洪水以来的首次大规模示威，当时;城外山上的两座水坝在一场强大的风暴中溃坝;，释放出毁灭性的洪流。

;

;抗议者还瞄准了官员，包括东部地区负责人利比亚议会阿吉拉·萨利赫在萨哈巴清真寺外举行示威活动。有些人坐在德尔纳地标金色圆顶前的屋顶上。

;

;利比亚东部政府表示，总理乌萨马·哈马德已解雇了德尔纳市议会的所有成员，并将他们移交调查。

;

;利比亚东部政府表示，总理乌萨马·哈马德已解雇了德尔纳市议会的所有成员，并将他们移交调查。 p>;

;“阿吉拉，我们不需要你。抗议者高呼“所有利比亚人都是兄弟”，呼吁在一个因十多年的冲突和混乱而政治分裂的国家实现民族团结。

; ;

;参加抗议活动的学生曼苏尔表示，他希望对大坝垮塌事件进行紧急调查，因为大坝垮塌“让我们失去了数千名心爱的人”。< /p>;

;另一名抗议者塔哈·米夫塔 (Taha Miftah) 表示，示威活动传递出“政府未能应对危机”的信息，并补充说议会尤其应该受到指责。

;

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 03:52:01 +0800 Freed American decries Iran’s ‘vile path to profit’ of holding foreigners hostagehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/18/iran-american-prisoner-swap-hostage-sanction-biden
;;2023-09-18T19:42:00Z;
;
;;Siamak Namazi and other former detainees arrive at the Doha international airport in Qatar on 18 September 2023.
;

;An American citizen freed in a complex exchange deal after being imprisoned for nearly eight years in Iran has urged the Biden administration to launch a “gamechanging global endeavour” to end the Islamic regime's longstanding practice of holding foreign nationals hostage.

;

;Siamak Namazi, 51, was one of five US citizens released on Monday under the terms of an agreement that saw five Iranians facing charges in the United States granted clemency and Iran being given access to $6bn of previously frozen oil revenues.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Five Americans head home in $6bn US-Iran prisoner swap deal ;

;
;

;The prisoners' release was hailed by President Joe Biden, who immediately announced fresh sanctions on the hardline former Iranian president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and the country's powerful intelligence ministry over the still undetermined fate of Robert Levinson, a retired FBI agent who vanished after visiting an island off Iran's southern coast in 2007.

;

;Biden also called on Americans – including those holding dual US-Iranian nationality – to avoid visiting Iran, which has been at loggerheads with Washington since 52 American embassy employees were held hostage in Tehran for 444 days in the aftermath of the 1979 Islamic revolution.

;

;However, Namazi – himself a dual national and the longest-hold of the five detainees after being imprisoned for 2,898 days, most of them inside Tehran's notorious Evin prison – in a statement called for a radically different approach to deter state-sponsored hostage taking.

;

;“Over the past 44 years, the Iranian regime has mastered the nasty game of caging innocent Americans and other foreign nationals, and commercialising their freedom,” he said after flying from Tehran to Doha, calling Evin prison a “dystopian United Nations of Hostages”.

;

;“We must urgently channel the grievous pain of the victims of this wickedness into the kind of measures that would upend the cost-benefit calculations of Tehran's foul business. For if we keep this vile path to profit free of risk and toll, this venal regime will keep treading on it. Again and again.

;

;“It is only if the free world finally agrees to collectively impose draconian consequences on those who use human lives as mere bargaining chips, that the Iranian regime and its ilk will be compelled to make different choices. Sadly, until then, we can anticipate more Americans and others falling victim to state hostage-taking.”

;

;Namazi's comments are likely to be seized on by Republicans who claimed that Iran is likely to use the unfrozen $6bn to fund terrorist activities.

;

;US officials insisted that the money will be restricted to “humanitarian transactions” involving food, medicine and medical supplies, and agricultural products.

;

;“This is not a payment of any kind,” a senior administration official said in an issued statement. “No funds enter Iran, nor do any funds get paid to Iranian companies or entities. At bottom, these are Iranian funds – payment made by South Korea to Iran for purchases of oil years ago, including during the last administration – moving from one restricted account in Korea to another restricted account in Qatar.”

;

;The funds were frozen in 2019 as a result of ramped-up sanctions imposed by the Trump administration as part of its policy of “maximum pressure” on Tehran. They related to oil bought from Iran by South Korea the previous year under a sanctions-waiver scheme.

;

;Biden, meanwhile, sought to shift the spotlight back to Iran by raising the plight of Levinson, whose fate has been a subject of speculation since he was reported missing in 2007, during Ahmadinejad's rumbustious presidency. His family announced that he was presumed dead in March 2020, after concluding on the advice of US officials that he died in Iranian custody.

;

;Iranian officials have never acknowledged detaining Levinson, while US officials believe he was held and interrogated by the country's intelligence agency as a possible bargaining chip.

;

;A retired FBI officer, he was initially reported to have visited Kish – an island frequented by tourists and not requiring a visa for entry – on a freelance investigation of illicit cigarette smuggling in March 2007.

;

;Interviewed by the late Charlie Rose on CBS five years later, Ahmadinejad did not deny that Levinson was being held and implied there had been talks of a prisoner exchange.

;

;An investigation from the Associated Press published in 2013 reported that Levinson had been working for the CIA on an unauthorised intelligence-gathering operation at the time of his disappearance.

;

;Biden declared hostage taking of US citizens a “national emergency” in an executive order issued in July last year.

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 03:52:01 +0800 UN summit sees western leaders defend slow progress to end global inequalityhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/18/un-summit-sees-western-leaders-defend-slow-progress-to-end-global-inequality

;

;Western leaders have gone on a charm offensive on the opening day of the UN general assembly as they were forced to defend their record in meeting the organisation's sustainable development goals (SDGs), and ;insist that ;the war in Ukraine had not distracted them from this commitment to end global inequality.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Rifts over Ukraine disrupt UN summit on crises in the global south;

;
;

;At a special summit in New York amounting to a halfway stocktake on progress towards meeting the goals by the target date of 2030, all sides acknowledged there was little chance that ;the ambitious set of commitments; set in 2015, including ending extreme poverty and safeguarding the environment, will be met on schedule.

;

;A plea by the UN secretary general, António Guterres, for all sides to avoid recriminations about the cause of the failure and instead to use the two-day summit as a chance to make a global rescue plan was only partially met on the opening day. The list of 17 SDGs, which includes 169 specific targets, was first adopted at the UN sustainable development summit in September 2015, and most assessments say only 15% of the targets are on track.

;

;The leaders adopted a 43-paragraph political declaration, brokered by Ireland and Qatar, that warned years of sustainable development gains were being reversed. It said: “Millions of people have fallen into poverty, hunger and malnutrition are becoming more prevalent, humanitarian needs are rising, and the impacts of climate change are more pronounced. This has led to increased inequality exacerbated by weakened international solidarity and a shortfall of trust to jointly overcome these crises”.

;

;“Instead of leaving no one behind, we risk leaving the SDGs behind … the SDGs need a global rescue plan,” Guterres told the summit.

;

;Guterres was able to see off a last-minute démarche – led by Russia and an alliance of only nine countries wanting to insert opposition to the use of unilateral sanctions into the declaration.

;

;The UN said this month that there were 745 million more people either moderately or severely hungry in the world today than in 2015, and the world was far off-track in its efforts to meet the ambitious goal to end hunger by 2030. The world was back at hunger levels not seen since 2005, and food prices remained higher in more countries than in the period 2015 –2019. On current progress it would also take 286 years to close the proposed gender gaps in legal protection and remove discriminatory laws.

;

;The solutions laid out in the political declaration are broad, covering financing for developing countries including clear support for Guterres' proposal for an SDG stimulus of at least $500bn annually, as well as a more effective debt-relief mechanism.

;

;The declaration also calls for changing the business model of multilateral development banks to offer private finance at more affordable rates for developing countries, and endorses reform of the international finance architecture which Guterrres has labelled “outdated, dysfunctional and unfair”.

; ;

;Dennis Francis, the president of the UN general assembly, said: “In the recent past there has been an unfortunate deficit of trust and this has undermined the capacity of the multilateral process.”

;

;Francis said “wounds still lingered over the handling of the pandemic”, reflecting a belief that affluent countries cherrypicked the targets they could meet. He insisted, however: “With concerted, ambitious action, it is still possible that, by 2030, we could lift 124 million additional people out of poverty and ensure that some 113 million fewer people are malnourished.”

;

;The agenda of the entire UN this week has been shaped to meet the concerns of the global south, including a separate climate summit on Wednesday, and it is evident that western powers – in a bid to counter Russian and Chinese influence – have in their round of bilateral and multilateral meetings put a heavy emphasis on the concerns of poorer countries.

;

;The Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, is expected to meet the sceptical Brazilian president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, on Wednesday in a bid to persuade him that the war in Ukraine is not an obstacle to progress for the world's poor, and that Ukraine's fate is a legitimate matter for the world, not just Europe.

;

;The German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, also admitted there had been a western failure in efforts to ensure sustainable development for the planet. He said: “We see that the progress we wanted for the whole world in the fight against poverty and for better coexistence has become slower.”

; ;

;Catherine Colonna, the French foreign minister, said she wanted to avoid a north-south fracture and emphasised France's role in building its aid budget and a new global financial pact. She went on the offensive, attacking Russia for its role in worsening the food scarcity crisis by bombing Ukraine's grain stores.

;

;She said: “The world can be broken down to those who destroy and threaten and those who build and feed. France is part of the coalition who help to make everyone not go hungry.” She said Russia's efforts to present itself as a member of the global south, a term she said she disliked, were designed to mislead.

;

;But the strength of the diplomatic olive branch to the global south was weakened by the glaring absence of two European leaders: Rishi Sunak, the British prime minister, and Emmanuel Macron, the French president. France's mission to the UN said Macron had a scheduling conflict, hosting Britain's King Charles III in Paris this week.

;

;The outreach at the general assembly is likely to be matched in coming months by that of European governments undertaking to meet smaller countries that have often been bypassed by high-ranking European ministers, let alone heads of state.

;

;Earlier this year 10 European countries, including Belgium and Slovenia, urged the European Union high representative, Josep Borrell, to coordinate a diplomatic campaign to woo countries that have felt ignored, citing the need to do a better job of competing with China and Russia in what Borrell has described as a “battle of narratives”.

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 03:22:01 +0800 People who work from home all the time ‘cut emissions by 54%’ against those in officehttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/sep/18/people-who-work-from-home-all-the-time-cut-emissions-by-54-against-those-in-office
;;2023-09-18T19:00:36Z;
;
;;A woman using a laptop on a dining room table
;

;People who work remotely all the time produce less than half the greenhouse gas emissions of office workers, according to a new study.

;

;Employees in the US who worked from home all the time were predicted to reduce their emissions by 54%, compared with workers in an office, the study found. But hybrid workers did not reduce their emissions so dramatically, according to the research ;published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences;.

;

;One day of remote work a week reduced emissions by just 2% because energy savings from not being in the office were offset by factors such as an increase in non-commuting travel when working from home. Working remotely two or four days a week reduced an individual's emissions by up to 29% compared with on-site workers.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Never again': is Britain finally ready to return to the office?;

;
;

;Researchers from Cornell University and Microsoft used multiple datasets including Microsoft's own employee data on commuting and teleworking behaviours to model the predicted greenhouse gas emissions of office workers, remote workers and hybrid workers in the US, examining five categories of emissions including office and residential energy use.

;

;They found that IT and communications technology had a negligible impact on individuals' work carbon footprints.

;

;The main causes of remote workers' reduced emissions were less office energy use, as well as fewer emissions from a daily commute.

;

;Wider emissions reducing benefits of working from home include the easing of vehicle congestion during rush hour in commuting areas, which is likely to improve fuel economy. But the authors warned that working from home needed to be carefully planned to deliver emissions saving benefits.

;

;“People say: 'I work from home, I'm net zero.' That's not true,” said the co-author ;Fengqi You of Cornell University;. “The net benefit for working remotely is positive but a key question is how positive. When people work remotely, they tend to spend more emissions on social activities.”

;

;The study found that remote workers' non-work travel increased, with more driving and more flying. You said that homes were not always optimised for decarbonisation, in terms of using renewable energy and the efficiency of appliances, and there were some scale-related energy savings. For instance, a small home printer is likely to be less energy efficient than an office printer.

;

;The Covid-19 pandemic created a remote working revolution for many office workers. In the US and elsewhere, many people relocated from “high-density commuting zones” – relatively close to major cities and offices – to more rural “low-density commuting zones”. According to the study, this could result in longer commuting distances for hybrid workers and a greater carbon footprint due to the increased use of private vehicles.

;

;The authors said: “While remote work shows potential in reducing carbon footprint, careful consideration of commuting patterns, building energy consumption, vehicle ownership, and non-commute-related travel is essential to fully realise its environmental benefits.”

;

;While the findings do not apply to workers in many sectors – a bus driver, for example, cannot work from home – it provides pointers on how office-based employers can reduce company emissions.

;

;You said that while the findings were specific to the US, the modelling and trends were likely to be replicated in Europe and Japan. He called on companies to look at energy efficiency measures, downsizing and sharing office space. “By sharing office space we reduce capacity and size and reduce our office energy consumption,” he said.

;

;The study found that IT and communications accounted for a small percentage of overall emissions and therefore emissions reduction should focus on renewables for office heating and cooling, as well as decarbonising commuting.
